summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the defense's motion to exclude the government's expert witness, Dr. Lisa Rocchio, in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The court largely denies the motion, finding Dr. Rocchio's testimony on grooming and trauma in sexual abuse cases admissible under the Daubert standard, but excludes one specific opinion about 'grooming-by-proxy'.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein and participating in the sexual abuse of minors.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge presiding over the case, authoring this opinion and order on the admissibility of expert testimony.

persons.name: Lisa Rocchio
persons.context: Clinical psychologist and proposed government expert witness on grooming, trauma, and the behavior of victims of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the predator with whom Maxwell conspired, who groomed and sexually abused minors.

connections.description: The government alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein, a predator who groomed and sexually abused minors.
Dr. Rocchio is the government's proposed expert witness whose testimony is intended to help the jury understand aspects of the case against Maxwell.

events.title: Daubert Hearing
events.description: Court hearing held to examine the admissibility of Dr. Lisa Rocchio's expert testimony.

events.title: Court Issues Opinion on Expert Testimony
events.description: Judge Nathan issues an opinion and order largely denying the defense's motion to exclude Dr. Rocchio's testimony, but excluding one specific opinion.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court ruled that Dr. Lisa Rocchio, an expert on trauma and sexual abuse, is qualified and her testimony on grooming is largely admissible in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

The court excluded one specific opinion from Dr. Rocchio: that the presence of a third party can facilitate grooming ('grooming-by-proxy'), finding it lacked sufficient support in the relevant literature.

The court found Dr. Rocchio's testimony relevant to help the jury understand how minors can be coerced without physical force and to rebut anticipated defense impeachment strategies regarding victim behavior.
The document confirms the government's theory that Maxwell both participated in abuse and conspired with Jeffrey Epstein, who groomed and abused minors.
